I can tell you that bliss can be interfaced with c or c++ due to their similar low-level capabilities, memory management structures, and its memory model. bliss can also be interfaced with assembly language, which may be necessary in some cases to write machine-specific modules.

interfaces between programming languages are usually done using "foreign function interfaces", which allow data to be passed between bliss and other languages. bliss language uses a standard calling convention to simplify the process of interfacing with other languages.

in general, interfacing with other programming languages becomes necessary when the specific strengths of those languages make them advantageous for a particular task. 

for example, when performing data analysis, bliss may not have the necessary libraries, and complex tasks may be better handled by python or r. using these languages alongside bliss can offer a mix of low-level control and high-level libraries necessary for the task.

another instance where bliss could be interfaced with another programming language is in building system-level components, drivers or device interfaces with specialized hardware. c or c++ are generally used in these types of cases, and bliss could handle the complex hardware by interfacing with it, while c or c++ would interface with the operating system apis.

in summary, bliss can interface with c or c++, allowing it to tap into libraries that otherwise, bliss might not offer. when the complexity of the task requires a more straightforward interface to a lower-level language, or when specific libraries are needed, interfacing bliss with other languages becomes essential.
